Abstract. We dene new symbol classes for pseudodierential operators and investigate
their pseudodierential calculus. The symbol classes are parametrized by commutative con-
volution algebras. To every solid convolution algebra A over a lattice  we associate a symbol
class M ,A. Then every operator with a symbol in M ,A is almost diagonal with respect

on L2(Rd). If a version of Wieners lemma holds for A, then the algebra of pseudodierential
operators is closed under inversion. The theory contains as a special case the fundamen-

1. Introduction
We study pseudodierential operators with symbols that are dened by their time-frequency
distribution (phase-space distribution). The rst symbol class of this type was introduced by
Sjostrand [39, 40] whose work has inspired an important line of research by Boulkhemair, Toft,
and others [9, 10, 44, 45, 46, 35]. Independently, an alternative approach with time-frequency
methods was developed in [28, 29, 24, 26, 27]. The starting point of the time-frequency
approach is the observation that the Sjostrand class coincides with one of the so-called mod-
ulation spaces that were introduced by Feichtinger already in 1983 [17]. The time-frequency
approach added several new insights and generalizations to pseudodierential operators with
non-smooth symbols. Recently Sjostrand has again taken up the study of pseudodierential
operators with non-smooth symbols and substantially generalized the original denition [41].
His motivation is to study weighted symbol spaces, the boundedness and algebra properties
of the corresponding pseudodierential operators.
In this paper we also study extensions of the original Sjostrand class. Our goal is to
understand better the following fundamental questions:
Which properties of the generalized Sjostrand class are responsible for the boundedness
of the corresponding pseudodierential operators on L2(Rd) and on other function
spaces?
Which properties of the symbol class imply the algebra property of the operators?

As another application of our main results, we will investigate the action of pseudodier-
ential operators on time-frequency molecules and the almost diagonalization of pseudodier-
ential operators with respect to time-frequency molecules. This topic is hardly explored yet,
and ours seems to be the rst results in pseudodierential operator theory.
Throughout the paper we use methods from time-frequency analysis (phase-space analysis)
and Banach algebra methods. We draw on properties of the short-time Fourier transform
and the Wigner distribution and the theory of the associated function spaces, the modulation
spaces. For the investigation of the almost diagonalization of pseudodierential operators we
will use the well-developed theory of Gabor frames, which provide a kind of non-orthogonal
phase-space expansions of distributions.The main sources are the books [21, 24]. Another set
of tools comes from the theory of Banach algebras. The inverse-closedness as expressed in
Theorem D lies quite deep and requires some new results on Banach algebras with respect
to convolution. Although the proof techniques are classical, these arguments seem unusual
in the theory of pseudodierential operators; we therefore give the proofs in the Appendix.
